Figuring in the story are gas station attendants, motel owners, bus drivers and bus stations, all part of the newly emerging automobile age. A movie of this kind could not have set in a pre-auto culture. This accounts for the movie's contemporary feel. Clark Gable so dominates this movie that it is virtually impossible to imagine anyone else playing Peter Warne. Yet, what makes the movie succeed is its straightforward storytelling about people who want to be break free from the social conventions that are denying them happiness. review_title: Practically flawless cinema from Frank Capra
review_detailed_main:
Frank Capra's "It Happened One Night" may be his finest picture, which is somewhat surprising since it doesn't exhibit the trademark Capra style of later films like "Mr. Smith Goes to Washington" or "It's a Wonderful Life". No, "It Happened One Night" is an unabashed romantic comedy and one of the best (if not the very best) of all time.

The story concerns a spoiled heiress (Claudette Colbert), on the run from her controlling father, who meets up with an unemployed newspaper reporter (Clark Gable) on a night bus to New York. They decide to work together to their mutual advantage but what starts out as a business arrangement gradually develops into something more.

The film's embarrassment of riches begins with its stars. Not only do they deliver excellent performances individually but together they have wonderful chemistry. Gable's performance is probably the best of the two but both were deserving Oscar winners. Besides these two, the cast is uniformly solid, including supporting standouts Walter Connolly & Roscoe Karns.

The film is distinguished as the first to win all five major Academy Awards. Besides the aforementioned Oscars for Best Actor & Best Actress, the film also took home Oscars for its adapted screenplay (by Robert Riskin) and direction (by Frank Capra) along with the prestigious Best Picture Oscar. Only three films have ever captured all five awards. Pretty elite company, to be sure, but well warranted given the quality of each contribution.

In the end, "It Happened One Night" is a film that's practically without fault. Despite being over 75 years old it's still as vibrant as the day it was released. Without a doubt, it's a must-see for any self-respecting film fan.

I love love LOVE road movies. Something about traveling the open road and getting into antics is fun. And makes the world a bigger place. From Preston Sturges "Sullivan's Travels" to "Rain Man" road movies just remind you that America is a place for adventure. This is no different. Here they go from Miami to New York. I love seeing what that generation behaved like. And it isn't that much different than how we are now.

Here is the story of an heiress Ellie (Claudette Colbert) who runs away to meet up with a man she is in love with. Undercover as a "commoner" she comes across the cad Peter Warne (Clarke Gable). He is a rebel newspaper writer who's, somewhat, lost his writing skills. Their chance meeting leads to Peter wanting the scoop on her motives for running away. They bicker incessantly but we all see they are falling in love.

Yes, this is template of both a road movie AND a screwball comedy. The lines often come fast and furious so you have to catch them.

Modern audiences beware, there are, what some may consider, misogynistic undertones. HOWEVER, Ellie tends to dish out more than she gets.

This film is a classic for a reason. As a reminder, this flick was a few years after the Great Depression. Yet, some things still remain true. Love, community, learning empathy. All great messages without being hammered over the head with the messages.

This is one of the moments in cinema that make you proud to make films.

First Screwball Comedy and First to Win the 'Big Five' Academy Awards
review_detailed_main:
It's rare the Academy Awards hands out the 'Big Five' Oscars to one motion picture: Best Picture, Best Director, Best Actor, Best Actress and Best Adapted Screenplay. In fact, only two other films hold that honor after February 1934's "It Happened One Night" achieved the seemingly impossible. Strangely, the Columbia Pictures' movie was initially a production no one wanted to be involved. Several top-flight stars rejected having anything to do with the production after reading the script, including Miriam Hopkins, Myrna Loy, Margaret Sullavan, Frederic March and Robert Montgomery, who later called it the worst screenplay he had ever read. Columbia boss Harry Cohn recommended actress Claudette Colbert to director Frank Capra to play the role of 'Ellie' Andres, who escapes from her wealthy father by diving off his Florida yacht to return to New York to re-unite with her recently married husband. Her father loathes the man and demands the marriage be annulled. Colbert had bad memories dealing with Capra in the first movie she ever appeared in, 1927's silent 'For the Love of Mike," and vowed never to work for him again. To discourage the hiring, she demanded double her salary of $50,000. Surprisingly, Columbia met her request.

Capra, after hearing so many actors reject the screenplay, asked his writer friend Myles Connolly what he thought of the script. His advice: make Ellie more sympathetic. Screenwriter Robert Riskin reworked the script based on Samuel Hopkins Adams' 1933 short story 'Night Bus' to do just that. Still, the rewrite didn't improve Colbert's disposition on the set. She bickered with Capra throughout the four weeks of filming. She told her friends "I just finished the worst picture in the world."

Clark Gable was equally unenthusiastic about the project. MGM loaned out the actor since his next studio film wasn't ready for some weeks, and his $2,000 a-week salary would be paid by Columbia. His first words to Capra on the initial day of shooting was "Let's get this over with."

Once "It Happened One Night" was released to major city theaters, critics were lukewarm towards the film. The New Yorker review scathingly wrote "pretty much nonsense and quite dreary." The initial short run at the large city movie houses was drawing only a mediocre audience. The film then played at smaller venues and towns. Suddenly, through word of mouth, lines formed out the door anxious to see Gable, as Peter Warne, a jaded know-it-all newspaper reporter just fired from his job who meets up with Ellie on the bus journeying north from Florida. The movie struck a special cord to rural Americans who were experiencing a lack of jobs, food, and shelter during the Depression. Roger Ebert noted in his review of "It Happened One Night, "The communal singing of "The Man on the Flying Trapeze" interrupts the action and morphs into a wonderfully democratic vision of the night bus as a society in eternal transit."

That bus ride scene was particularly instructive in how Capra, through his years of living in poverty, instinctively reframed it in the middle of filming. The director at first hired a small band to play "The Man on the Flying Trapeze" to a bus full of lower class travelers, including the two leads. Amazingly, all the extras knew the entire words to the song and sang it on the set. "Another idea." recalls Capra. "Why not let the whole bus join in? And that's what finally evolved." He praised small Columbia for allowing such independence that larger studios would have a committee of executives deciding on the director's preference.

"It Happened One Night" is filled with such classic scenes. When a bridge washed out the road during a rainstorm delaying the bus, Ellie and Peter are forced to share a motel room. The script called for Gable to strip down to his undies, describing each phase of his undressing. Gable's slick-tongue narrative got hung up when he had to remove his undershirt. Capra decided to bag the T-shirt. Gable's dialogue flowed smoothly after that. The sequence was so popular the males in the audience stopped buying undershirts, causing a massive drop in T-shirt sales.

Another scene is the famous hitch-hiking sequence where the two are forced to stake a ride. After Peter is unsuccessful using his thumb, Ellie tries the approach by raising her skirt and showing some leg. A body double was used for the close-up. Colbert was appalled. "That's not my leg!" she exclaimed, and insisted her leg be used instead.

"It Happened One Night" is credited as cinema's first screwball comedy. Even though loose versions of the farcical genre had been around since Shakespeare, including 'As You Like It,' the format didn't really pick up steam until Columbia's film. Movie critic Andrew Sarris defined screwballs as "sex comedy without the sex." The commonality all the screwball comedies have is the quick-paced dialogue, with romantic relationships set in hilarious situations, and containing occasional class distinctions of the middle-class seen as 'heroes' while the upper-class members looking like saps.

Even though "It Happened One Night" cleaned up at the box office in the secondary market, Colbert agreed with the sophisticated critics who gave a thumbs down to the movie. She was so sure she had no chance of winning the Academy Awards Best Actress, Colbert, despite her nomination, was seen boarding a train from Los Angeles to vacation in Phoenix during the evening of the ceremony. An Academy representative rushed to the station to inform her she had just won. Colbert went back to the Biltmore Hotel's gathering to accept the award. Film footage showing the evening's winners captures Colbert attired in traveling clothes.

"It Happened One Night" was the first to capture the 'Big Five" awards. The other two were 1975's "One Flew Over the Cuckoo's Nest" and 1991's "The Silence of the Lambs." Members of the American Film Institute rank the Capra film the 35th Best American Movie, the 8th Funniest, the 38th Most Passionate, the third Best Romantic Comedy, and nominated Ellie's quote, "Well, I proved once and for all that the limb is mightier than the thumb" as the one of the Best Quotes in Film. It Happened One Night tells the story of Ellie Andrews (Claudette Colbert), the daughter of wealthy Wall Street man Alexander Andrews (Walter Connolly), who is marrying aviator King Westley (Jameson Thomas) out of rebellion, and can no longer bear for her life to be planned out for her and constantly be told what to do. He offers to help the charming yet naïve Ellie get to New York without getting stopped in exchange for exclusive rights for her story. The film then takes us on the journey of them discovering that they love each other, despite the slightly testy nature of their initial relationship.

With a powerhouse director like Frank Capra, it's no wonder why this film turned out as well as it did. In fact, it is the first film to ever win the "big 5" at the Academy Awards, which consists of the Best Picture, Best Director, Best Writing, Best Actor, and Best Actress awards. The only other films to accomplish this feat were One Flew Over the Cuckoo's Nest (1975) and The Silence of the Lambs (1991).

This film, as far as I know, established the blueprint for the modern Romantic Comedy, which it also deserves tremendous credit for. 'It Happened One Night' is, on paper, pure establishment: a Frank Capra-directed Hollywood hit (albeit a slow-building one) that famously won Academy Awards for Best Picture, Director, Actor, Actress, and Screenplay, then becoming the template for hundreds of romantic comedies that followed. It's apropos then that its title suggests a flicker of chance, an unperceivable dash of magic. Indeed, even now, 'It Happened One Night' carries the unmistakable tenor of a breakout hit, fueled by confidently zippy repartee and manic comic invention that almost none of the innumerable pretenders to the throne of romantic comedy can match.

Clark Gable and Claudette Colbert star as a rakish newspaper reporter and a pampered and recently married heiress who fall for each other on a cross-country trip despite their clashing temperaments. The pair are as mismatched as can be: she's trying to get out from under her overbearing father's thumb (who's trying to annul her marriage) and runs away, and he selfishly smells the scoop of the century when he realizes who she is. No prizes for guessing whether they go from mutual irritation to attraction over the course of the trip, as what ensues are almost corrosive verbal fireworks between the two. He thinks she's a spoiled brat, and she believes he's a gruff, self-serving jackass. While they're both on the mark, this witty, hilarious picture, written by Capra-regular Robert Riskin, makes the most of this unlikely pair with its jagged and droll battle-of-the-sexes humor and unsentimental approach to romance.

Yes, it's a narrative that's been recycled countless times since, sometimes merely by using the genre conventions it helped to establish, like any movie where a pair of attracted non-lovers are forced to share a sleeping space. That's what Gable and Colbert do in the walls of Jericho scene, remembered for both its Biblical innuendo and its less allusive shot of a bare-chested Gable. There's also the much-spoofed scene where Colbert's Ellie schools Gable's Peter in hitchhiking technique, also predicated on a type of nudity that no longer qualifies as such. It's remarkable, then, that the '34 telling of this now-familiar story still feels fresh: always funny, still romantic, and quite beautiful to look at beyond even its two photogenic stars, matching the film's weaponized patter. There's a lot of deep and understated affection in the comedy, but the way the picture uses diverting sharp barbs to mask those sentiments is incredibly sophisticated for its time. Then again, maybe this film just indicates that I was born four decades too late.

Much of the film's progeny strive for that innate likability while missing one virtue of its not-quite-screwball pacing: simplicity. 'It Happened One Night' lets Peter and Ellie spend a lot of time together, focusing on their competing desires rather than the zany logistics of their travel arrangement. Their most famous scenes involve just the two of them, and many of the other sorta-important characters are either comic bit players or mostly offscreen. In the end, their romance, even with all of its twists turned into genre hallmarks, feels as quick and graceful as a magic trick, just as any classic romance should.

review_title: Classic Comedy About Sheltered Female and Strong Male=TNT
review_detailed_main: This script by Robert Riskin I find to be filled with excellent dialogue; This is an unpretentious but very idea-level social satire, involving the unlikely pairing of no-nonsense Clark Gable with classically-trained charismatic Claudette Colbert. The second unlikeliness about the film is the princess-like Colbert, being barred by her magnate father from consummating a secret marriage, jumping off the yacht where she is being confined and ending up being spotted by newsman Gable. He is in fact portrayed as the usual late-twenties hard-drinking no-nonsense reporter sort with three exceptions--he is adventurous, able to get along and function effectively at all levels of society even during the Depresssion, and he is working in a profession where there is no job-level between managing editor and field reporter; this all leaves him frustrated by dull or routine assignments but wanting to investigate and do something important in the world. Only the wealth of Colbert's father qualifies her as important. Once he befriends her, and agrees to get her where she wants to go, the added complication comes from their attraction for one another, a slowly growing and smoldering subtext to what they actually do. He disapproves of her; she disapproves of him. He represents, it appears to me, reality--what she has been denied every bit as much as any European princess ("The Princess Comes Across", "Roman Holiday") has been denied it; and he is a natural leader shut out from the upper levels of society and thus denied also; and he is the natural leader/mental aristocrat by ability denied her worlds of unobstructed goal-setting, doing one's one desires and not having to be disbarred from anything. As no one I know has noticed, then, this is a European story-line grafted onto a supposedly classless U.S., every bit as much so as is "Destry Rides Again" or "Roman Scandals". That I suggest is the secret to "It Happened One Night" and its strong story-line; it is a film about Gable's personal purpose of doing a good story for his career's sake and having it turned upside down by his falling in love with what Colbert ought-to-be, could be, and is becoming. The "Walls of Jericho" business involving the erecting of a curtain so Colbert will feel safe spending the night with Gable is a charming device for comedic purposes, as is Gable's removing his shirt as a symbol of reality-sexuality being offered to Colbert, the last thing she immediately wants to deal with. In another sense, the Walls are protecting him, the realist, from immediately having to deal with her higher-value-sexual meaning rather than her story-value to him as a reporter. The cleverness of the dialogue, picaresque adventures, human encounters and interactions depicted in the movie all magnify its importance again. And the fact that these are all beautifully presented by director Frank Capra and his technicians further increases their ability to affect an audience. The couple's different ways of handling people, the dunking of a donut, and the classic triumph of the bared female leg (hers) over hitchhiking expertise (his) at promoting them a ride become symbols of the natural triumphing over the artificial. over "barriers". And when the time comes for Ellie Andrews (Colbert) to decide whether she wants to stay married to one King Westley or divorce or marry Peter Warne (Gable), we the viewers have been well-informed as to what decision she will be making. This is a screwball-type comedy due to the unpredictable reactions of many persons to the Depression's unnatural restraints and emergencies. The basic situation--the princess-cheerleader female and the rough-hewn-commoner male has been carried out many times, but never with more success since the film's release; but this is essentially a European plot line grafted onto a U.S. stature-through-ability individualism; this is why so many attempts at this formula have failed, I suggest; because the formula was not understood, and because the united States has been increasingly unAmerican since 1902, particularly since 1937. The other interesting and important aspect I find as a writer is that Gable does not know who this waif is at the beginning; so we find that Gable's character is a commoner who deserves to be an important man, a first-rate newspaperman frustrated by his inability to chart his own course, a man who likes people who lives in a rough, noir-like environment, and a man who likes women and wants an equal but has to play mentor to a desirable woman only slowly realizing her potential. This is the "ice-goddess" aspect of the rich explored in "The Phildaelphia Story" by Philip Barry; Gable's problem is that of the great man stuck in a tsar-ridden society, familiar from "Holiday", "The Big Sleep" and "The Fountainhead" among others. The film I find is a delight; its dated aspects are those of its technologically backward period only. Its strengths appear to me to be derived from its honest plot and many interesting characters. Both leads are self-regulating; he lives by a moral code, and during the film she discovers the need for one. They seem to be an excellent match, when all is said and done. The evils of the Depression, which socialist Capra might have stressed even more than he does, are used very cleverly here as a background to the personal self-discovery mutual story-line. This is a well-photographed and artistic effort, I suggest, but nothing as stylish as Capra's later efforts. Cinematography by Joseph Walker, art direction by Stephen Goosson, and Robert Kalloch's costumes, with brief music only being provided all add to the realistic sense of the two character's descent from riches or daily reality and their immersion in the wider meaning of a nation in social upheaval and economic distress. In the cast the viewer should note Walter Connolly as Colbert's exasperated banker father, Roscoe Karns, Ward Bond, Alan Hale, Arthur Hoyt, Jameson Roberts, Harry Hume, Milton Kibbee and many more persons effective in brief parts. This is a well-designed movie, very deserving of its popularity.

This was touted to me as "the screwball comedy." It's real goodthere many, many jokes that are still funny today and great chemistry between the leads. I might, however, recommend Bringing Up Baby over It Happened One Night. I'm not sure, so I'll encourage anyone reading this to watch both. The screwball comedies of the 1930's all contain a nourishing endorsement of 'happily ever after,' not only as a possible destination and resting place, but as a necessary one. 'Happily Ever After' is fated in these movies, and we have the comforting pleasure of watching the two potential lovers find their way into that paradise. Romeo and Juliet with a happy ending, the crossing stars of two star-crossed lovers being untangled.

Broke and desperate, Ellie Andrews (Claudette Colbert), a young heiress trying to get back to her new husband of whom her wealthy father disproves, ends up travelling up the east coast on the cheap with Peter Warne (Clark Gable), a reporter who agrees to help her in exchange for an 'exclusive' story. As a comedy, Frank Capra's almost 90 year old light-weight romance has not aged all that well but as a pleasant snapshot of America in the '30s, it's great. Famously, the film cleaned up at the Oscars and the direction, cast, and script are all very good. Gable, one of Hollywood's iconic leading men, is willing to play the fool at times, (gnawing on carrots, ineffectually spitting, etc) something I always like in a 'star' and Colbert is great as the somewhat naïve, almost waifish 'spoiled rich girl'. The plot follows the usual 'meet cute - bonding adventures - love acknowledged - final-obstacle surmounted' trajectory but is enjoyable (and likely seemed a lot more original in the early 30s than now, after decades of similar storylines). The film was made before strict enforcement of the Hays Code, so the humour is slightly sly and risqué (although no more than many of the subsequent 'screwball comedies', which snuck a lot past Mrs. Grundy's censorious eyes). All in all, a fun slice of Americana and Hollywood history - cute, quaint, clever, and well worth a watch at a number levels (and one reason why I don't wear an undershirt).

I've lately been watching a number of films made in the early 30's and it just strikes me watching "It Happened One Night" how unlike all the others it was, good as they sometimes were. I know it was the first screwball comedy, something in itself, but it's Capra's moving camera, the snappy dialogue and the credible acting even in unlikely situations that make you feel less like you're watching something staged. In all those senses, it plays like the first modern movie. Crazy as they sometimes are, Gable and Colbert's characters feel like real people, talking and acting naturally as they go. It's also a film made for adults to enjoy, the for-the-times risqué humour concerning the erection (no pun intended) of the symbolic Walls of Jericho between the thrown together couple, Gable's undressing to his bare torso, Colbert's hitching a ride for them by provocatively hitching her skirt and the closing consummation scene where the walls come tumbling down are all knowingly and winningly rendered.

Gable is great in the role that elevated him to his unchallenged status as the King Of Hollywood, the personification of contemporary masculinity, handsome, confident and honourable and yet not without sensitivity or good manners. Colbert is equally good as the spoiled brat who is brought down to earth on the road with Gable. She's sexy, sassy and chic and every bit the match of Gable, a prototype for the smart-talking female characters to be played in succeeding Hollywood comedies starring the likes of Rosalind Russell, Katharine Hepburn, Jean Arthur, Barbra Stanwyck, Carole Lombard and others. The starring couple's interaction and comic timing is perfect, a model for all those initially-warring-couple features for years to come.

With a witty script by Robert Ruskin, an able supporting cast and a succession of humorous situations, the film flows beautifully from the off, never letting up, directed energetically and at times almost instinctively by Capra in the movie that really made his name. There are no lingering close-ups, static scene-setting or slow dissolves here, it's all pace and movement as befits the plight of the runaway couple.

Capra's social commentary is still evident and doesn't gloss over its Depression Era setting, manifest in the scene when Gable salutes the everyday folk riding the top of the train which crosses his path. Capra didn't really return to screwball comedy after making this, instead going on in later years to further exercise his conscience by employing Messrs Deeds, Smith and Doe, but he didn't need to, he nailed it forever with this marvellous one-off collective collaboration, almost unbelievably shot in only four weeks.

review_title: A classic rom-com that is ageless in its joy
review_detailed_main:
Famed Italian/American director Frank Capra certainly deserves his revered reputation as one of the all time great filmmakers with masterpiece films like Mr. Smith Goes to Washington and Christmas favourite It's a Wonderful Life key pieces of his filmography but its arguable while not perhaps his best film in the pure sense of the word, Capra's It Happened One Night is his most influential film laying the foundation for all romantic comedies that would come in its wake.

Coming before strict movie making codes were bought into effect in America and going on to be one of only a handful of films in history to clean sweep all the major categories on Oscar night, Night in many ways was one of those rare examples were the stars aligned perfectly to allow Capra and his lead acting duo of the Oscar winning Clark Gable (on loan to do this film as punishment following on from an infamous affair) and the never better Claudette Colbert who heated up the screen with chemistry as the mismatched but also perfectly fit for one another Peter Warne and Ellie Andrews.

Coming across each others paths as Gable's smooth talking and roguish reporter Warne tracks down a story relating to Andrews heiress being on the run from her millionaire father, what follows in the wake of this simple set-up will be familiar to anyone that has since seen a romantic comedy from the Hollywood system but at the time of Night's arrival this was a new and fresh take on romance and comedy and while it may not be perfect, there's very few if any films of this era that could manage to stand the test of time as well as Night as nearing these 100 years on from release.

While there's many elements that help Night become the enjoyable and witty outing it becomes such as Capra's assured direction and screenwriter Robert Riskin's pitch perfect scripting there's no denying that the ace up the films sleeve is the spark and magic that comes from Gable and Colbert's performances together and watching the two Hollywood legends ply their trade alongside one another is one of the great sights of old school Hollywood history.

Pushing things to the limits with nighttime rituals (and sheet hangings), a whole lot of legs and suggestive dialogue that never falls to the wrong side of crass, watching the relationship between Warne and the sheltered but determined Andrews blossom is one of the finest examples of romance committed to the comedic genre and while the film never really heads into belly laugh territory the perfectly in tune balance of wit and romance found in Night put's many modern efforts to shame, highlighting why Capra's classic remains a beloved feature in the public spotlight.

Final Say -

The grandfather of the romantic comedy genre as we now know it, It Happened One Night hasn't aged a day since it first appeared in 1934 as Capra and his acting team take viewers on a joyful road trip that is sure to bring a smile to all that are lucky enough to catch it.

Although I readily admit that Frank Capra knew what he was doing as a director, I do not rate him in the same quality band as my favorite directors William Wyler, Alfred Hitchcock, François Truffaut, Fritz Lang, Fred Zinnemann, or Billy Wilder. That said, I find IT HAPPENED ONE NIGHT his finest hour, far better than perhaps his best known movie, IT'S A WONDERFUL LIFE, which sickened me with its 'overschmaltziness'. There is a point of contact between those two Capra-directed flicks: both turn on the financial problems of the male lead (Clark Gable and Jimmy Stewart, respectively). Perhaps it has to do with the poverty Capra grew up in: born in Sicily, he traveled by ship to the United States and described the trip as loads of passengers vomiting from beginning to end, and the lingering stench apparently never left his nostrils - nor did poverty in his early years in Uncle Sam.

Though I consider Stewart to have put out a higher quality body of work over the course of his career, I find Gable's Peter Warne more likable than any character Stewart played for Capra.

Claudette Colbert also deserves high praise. Her round face is not my ideal in terms of female beauty, but she has a lovely figure, great legs and once she smiles she is to die for and I forget any imperfections.

Back to IT HAPPENED, regrettably I watched a badly cropped copy on Youtube. Probably unfairly, it causes me to dock two stars. Still, cinematography by Joseph Walker is highly skilled and the script by Robert Riskin so imaginative and ground-breaking that it has been credited with starting the 1930s spate of screwball comedies.

Definitive must see, very likely an influence on Alfred Hitchcock and his THE 39 STEPS masterpiece that would come out in the United Kingdom the following year. 8/10.
